content.webTitle: Jessica Fox wins bronze in K1 canoe as Australian men claim rowing silver

fields.headline: Jessica Fox wins bronze in K1 canoe as Australian men claim rowing silver
fields.bodyText: Australia has won a silver medal in the men’s rowing quad sculls in Rio, with the crew of Karsten Forsterling, Sasha Belonogoff, Cameron Girdlestone and James McRae finishing in second place behind defending champions Germany. The Australians had entered the event as favourites and were undefeated this year, but the German team came out strong to establish an early lead they’d never relinquish in a strong headwind and took out the 2000m race. The Germans were defending their title from London and the event had originally been scheduled for day five of the Games but was postponed on account of weather conditions. Estonia took out the bronze. Crew veteran Karsten Forsterling told reporters, “We rely on building momentum in the second 1,000 metres and that’s our strength. But we got knocked about early in the race and it’s hard to build momentum up again. The Germans were clear and it’s hard to close down that margin.” Australia’s other medal of the night went to Jessica Fox, when the world No1 added a bronze medal in the K1 canoe slalom to the silver she won at the London Games. Fox had a two-second penalty in her final run with two gates remaining and finished behind Maialen Chourraut of Spain and New Zealand’s Luuka Jones. Fox crossed the line in first position but said it was a “fair call” that judges had docked her time following a video review that confirmed she’d touched a gate during her run, which put New Zealand’s Luuka Jones into the lead, but both the Kiwi and Fox moved down one placing when Spain’s Maialen Chourraut raced through a near-perfect run to claim gold with a time of 98.65. “I haven’t checked the video but I’m sure it’s probably there,” Fox told ABC. “It’s hard to know but I came in tight, it wasn’t a perfect upstream and I knew that I slid out so the touch could have been there.” Elswehere, two wins and a fourth place have taken Australian sailing cousins Jason Waterhouse and Lisa Darmanin to the top of the Nacra 17 rankings five races into competition. Over at the pool, Cameron McEvoy has regrouped from his disappointment in the 100m freestyle final to cruise through to the 50m semi-finals. McEvoy clocked 21.80 seconds to be fifth fastest in the one-lap dash heats. At the velodrome, Australia’s team sprint trio of Matthew Glaetzer, Nathan Hart and Patrick Constable narrowly missed out on Australia’s first cycling medal of the games, beaten into fourth as Team GB claimed gold. Australia looked capable of bronze when they led France into the third and final lap, but fell short to finish one spot out of the medals for the fourth consecutive Games. “That’s sport. We have been on the winning side of that scenario before,” Glaezter said after the race. “We were definitely aiming for medals – it’s always disappointing not to get on the podium, but I’m really proud of the boys.” In tennis, Australia’s mixed doubles pairing of Samantha Stosur and John Peers went down to India’s fourth seeds Sania Mirza and Rohan Bopanna 5-7, 4-6 at the Olympic Tennis Centre, meaning they miss out on a quarter final clash with Brits Heather Watson and Andy Murray, the latter of whom made a surprise appearance after receiving a late call-up.
